editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Wise-woman of Hogsdon
Wise-woman of Hogsdon.

div.p: As it hath been sundry times acted with great applause.
Printed by m. P. for Henry Shephard, and are to be sold at his shop in Chancerie-lane, at the sign of the bible, between Sergeants-inn and Fleetstreet. 1638.

list.item: Sir Harry, a knight, who is no piece of a scholar.
Sir Boniface, an ignorant pedant, or schoolmaster.
The wise-woman of Hogsdon, who bears the name of the drama.
A countryman, client to the wise-woman.
A kitchenmaid, and two citizens' wives, that come to the wise-woman for counsel.

div.head: Actus primus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter, as newly come from play, four young gentlemen, master Chartley, master Sencer, m. Boyster; and master Haringfield.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: Price of my life: now if the devil have bones, these dice are made of his. Was ever such a cast seen in this age? Could any gull in Europe (Saving myself) fling such a cast?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Eye.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes.

lg.l: But I say no: I have lost an hundred pound,
And I will have my saying.
I have lost another hundred, I'll have mine.
Ay, yes, I flung a worse: a worse by odds.
I cry you mercy sir, losers' may speak,
I'll not except 'gainst you: but let me see
Which of these two that pocket up our cash
Dares contradict me?
Sir, not I:
I say you have had bad casting.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: So say I.

lg.l: I say this hat's not made of wool
Which of you all dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: It may be 'tis a 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Very likely 〈…〉 beaver.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: 〈…〉 would fain pick a quarrel with them, to get some of my money again; but the slaves slaves they have goted it are too wise to part with it.
I say it is not black.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: So say we too.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: 'Tis false: his cap's of wool, ▪ 'tis black, and wool, and wool and black.

lg.l: I have naught to say to losers.
Have I nothing left to set at a cast? Ay finger,
Must you be set in gold, and not a jot of silver in my purse?
A bale of fresh dice. Ho, come at this ring.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Fie m. Chartley, 'tis time to give over.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That's the winners phrase: hold me play; or he that hath uncrowned me, I'll take a speedy order with him.

lg.l: Fresh dice: this ●ewell I will venture more
Take this and all. I'll play in spite of luck.
Since you will needs; trip for the dices.
I see it is hard to go a winner from this company.
The dice are mine:
This diamond I value at twenty marks:
I'll venture it at a throw.

sp.p: 'Tis for you.

lg.l: Then at all. All's mine. Nay m. Boyster,
I bar you: let us work upon the winners.
Gramercy Sinks: nay, though I owe you no quarrel, yet you must give me leave to draw.
I had rather you should draw your sword,
Then draw my money thus.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Again sweet dice: nay I bar swearing, gentlemen, let's play patiently. Well, this at the candlestick, so —

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Now dice at all. To though, quoth the Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Here's precious luck.

lg.l: 〈◊〉 〈◊〉. I think 'tis quicksilver;
It comes and goes so fast: there's life in this.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: He passes all with trays.

lg.l: With Trayes, how say by that
O he's old dog at bowls and Trayes.
Lend me some money: be my half one cast.
I'll once outbrave this gamester with a throw
So now the dice are mine, will't be my half?

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: I will.

lg.l: Then once I'll play the frank gamester.
Let me but see how much you both can make,
And I'll cast at all, all, every cross.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Now bless us all, what will you every cross 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I will not leave myself one cross to bless me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I set.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why then at all. How ▪

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Nay, swear not, let's play patiently.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Damned dice: did ever gamester see the like?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Never, never.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Was ever known such casting?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Drunk nor sober, I never saw a man cast worse.

lg.l: I'll prove this hat of mine an helmet.
Which of you here dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Chart:
sp.p: As fair an helmet as any man in Europe needs to wear.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Chartley, thy hat is black.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Upon better recollection, 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I say 'tis made of wool.

lg.l: True, my losing had taken away my senses,
Both of seeing and feeling: but better luck
Hath brought them to their right temper.
But come, a pox of dice; 'tis time to give over.
All times are times for winners to give over,
But not for them that lose. I'll play till midnight,
But I will change my luck.
Come, come, you shall not.
Give over: tush give over: do I pray,
And choose the fortune of some other hour:
Let's not like debauched fellows, play our clothes,
Belts, rapiers, nor our needful ornaments:
'Tis childish, not becoming gentlemen.
Play was at first ordained to pass the time;
And sir, you but abuse the use of play,
To employ it other wise.
You may persuade me —
For once I'll leave a loose●.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then come put on your helmet; let's leave this abominable game, and find out some better exercise. I cannot endure this chafing when men lose.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: And there's not a more testy waspish companion than thyself when thou art a looser, and yet thou must be vexing others with, play patiently gentlemen, and let's have no swearing.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: A sign that I can give good counsel better than take it: but say, where be the prettiest wenches, my hearts?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Well remembered, this puts me in mind of an appointment I had with a gentlewoman of some respect.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I have you sir, I have you; but I think you will never have her: 'tis Gratiana the knight's daughter in gracious street. Have I touched you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: You have come somewhat near me, but touched me not. Master Haringfield, will you bear me company thither? Have you seen the gentlewoman, m. Chartley?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: How have you heard of her?

lg.l: That she hath, as other women have,
That she goes for a maid, as others do, etc.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I can assure you, she is a proper gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then if she have you, she is like to have a proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: You should tell them so that know it not. Adieu gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I am glad yet they go so lightly away.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What will you do m. Boyster?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Somewhat.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You will not acquaint me with your business.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: No: I am in love, my head is full of proclamations. There is a thing called a virgin. Nature hath showed her art in making her. Court her I cannot, but I'll do as I may.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Do you go, or stay sir?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Go.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You before, I'll follow. He thinks with his blunt humour, to enter as far as I with my sharp: no, my true Trojan, no: there is a fair sweet modest rogue, her name is luce: with this dandiprat, this pretty little ape's face, is yond blunt fellow in love; and no marvel, for she hath a brow bewitching, eyes ravishing, and a tongue enchanting: and indeed she hath no fault in the world but one, and that is, she is honest: and were it not for that, she were the only sweet rogue in Christendom. As I live, I love her extremely, and to enjoy her would give any thing: but the fool stands in her own light, and will do nothing without marriage: but what should I do marrying? I can better endure gives, than bands of matrimony. But in this meditation, I am glad I have won my money again. Nay, and she may be glad of it too: for the girl is but poor, and in my pocket I have laid up a stock for her, 'tis put to use already. And if I meet not with a dice-house, or an ordinary by the way, no question but I may increase it to a sum. Well, I'll unto the exchange to buy her some pretty novelty: that done, I'll visit my little rascal, and solicit instantly.

div.head: Actus primus, scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Luce in a sempster's shop, at work upon a laced handkercher, and Joseph a prentice.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Where is my father? Joseph.

lg.l: Mistress, above,
And prays you to attend below a little.
I do not love to sit thus publicly:
And yet upon the traffic of our wares,
Our provident eyes and presence must still wait.
Do you attend the shop, I'll ply my work.
I see my father is not jealous of me,
That trusts me to the open view of all.
The reason is, he knows my thoughts are chaste,
And my care such, as that it needs the awe
Of no strict overseer.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yonder's Luce. Save thee.

lg.l: And you too, sir, you're welcome; want you ought,
I pray, in which our trade may furnish you?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Joseph, show the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: 'Tis here that I would buy.

lg.l: What do you mean sir, speak, what is't you lack?
I pray you wherefore do you fix your eyes
So firmly in my face? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yes, thee.

lg.l: Your pleasure is to jest, and so I take it.
Pray give me leave sir, to intend my work.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: You are fair.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You flout me.

lg.l: You are, go too, you are,
I'd vex him that should say the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Well, you may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O sir!

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: As I live, I do.

lg.l: Now as I am a true maid,
The most religious oath that I dare swear,
I hold myself indebted to your love:
And I am sorry there remains in me,
No power how to requite it.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Love me, prithee now, do if thou canst ▪

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Prithee, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yet ask thine heart, and see what may be done.

lg.l: In troth I am sorry you should spend a ●igh
For my sake unrequited, or a tear;
Ay, or a word ▪
'Tis no matter for my words, they are not many,
And those not very wise one's neither.
Yet I beseech you spend no more in vain.
I scorn you not; disdains as far from me,
As are the two poles distant: therefore sir,
Because I would not hold you in suspense,
But tell you what at first to trust unto,
Thus in a word, I must not fancy you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Must not?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot, nor I may not.

lg.l: I am gone:
Thou hast given me, Luce, a bone to gnaw upon ▪

sp.speaker: Luc●.

lg.l: Alas, that beauty should be sought of more
Than can enjoy it: might I have my wish,
I would seem fair but only in his eye,
That should possess me in a nuptial tie.

sp.stage: Enter young master Chattley, with gloves, ring, purse, etc..

lg.l: Morrow Luce; in exchange of this kiss, see
what I have brought thee from the exchange.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What mean you sir, by this?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Guess that by the circumstance, here's a ring ▪ wear't for my sake; twenty angels, pocket them you fool; come, come, I know thou art a maid, say nay, and take them.

lg.l: Sweet master Chartley, do not fasten on me,
More than with ease I can shake off: your gift
I reverence, yet refuse; and I pray tell me,
Why do you make so many errands hither?
Send me so many letters? fasten on me
So many favours? what's your meaning in't?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hark in thine ear, I'll tell thee; nay hear me out, is't possible so soft a body should have so hard a soul? Nay now I know my penance, you will be angry, and school me for tempting your modesty: a fig for this modesty, it hinders many a good man from many a good turn, and that's all the good it doth. If thou but knewest, Luce, how I love thee, thou wouldst be far more tractable. Nay, I bar chiding when you speak ▪ I'll stop thy lips if thou dost but offer an angry word, by this hand I'll do't, and with this hand too. Go to now, what say you?

lg.l: Sir, if you love me, as you say you do,
Show me the fruits thereof.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The stock I can, thou mayst see the fruits hereafter.

lg.l: Can I believe you love me, when you seek
The ship wrack of mine honour?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Honour! there's another word to flap in a man's mouth: honour! what shouldst thou and I stand upon our honour, that were neither of us yet, right worshipful?

lg.l: I am sorry sir, I have lent so large an ear
To such a bad discourse; and I protest
After this hour, never to do the like.
I must confess, of all the gentlemen
That ever courted me, you have possessed
the best part in my thoughts: but this course language
Exiles you quite from thence. Sir, had you come,
In stead of changing this mine honest name
Into a strumpet's, to have honoured me
With the chaste title of a modest wife;
I had reserved an ear for all your suits:
But since I see your rudeness finds no limit,
I leave you to your lust.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You shall not, luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Then keep your tongue within more moderate bounds.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I will, as I am virtuous, I will: I told you, the second word would be marriage. It makes a man forfeit his freedom, and makes him walk ever after with a chain at his heels, or a jackanapes hanging at his elbow: marriage is like Dedalus his labyrinth, and being once in, there's no finding the way out. Well, I love this little property most intolerably, and I must set her on the last, though it cost me all the shoes in my shop. Well Luce, thou seest my stomach is come down; thou hast my heart already, there's my hand.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Nay, I know not the way yet, but I hope to find it hereafter, by your good direction.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I mean, in what manner? in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: In the way of marriage, in the way of honesty, in the way that was never gone yet: I hope thou art a maid, luce.

lg.l: Yes sir, and I accept it; in exchange
Of this your hand, you shall receive my heart.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: A bargain, and there's earnest on thy lips ▪

lg.l: I'll call my father, sir, to witness it:
See, here he comes.

div.stage: Enter her father, a plain citizen.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father, save you, you have happened of an untoward son-in-law; here I am, how do you like me?

lg.l: Sir, I was nearer than you were aware,
And overheard both sum and circumstance.
Then I perceive you are an old eavesdropper:
But what do you think of it, father?
I entertain the motion with all love,
And I rejoice my daughter is preferred,
And raised to such a match; I heard the contract,
And will confirm it gladly: but pray sir,
When shall the merry day be?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Marry, even tomorrow by that we can see; my, we'll lose no more time, I'll take order for that.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Stay but a month.

sp.speaker: Ch●rt
sp.p: A month I thou canst not hire me to't. Why Luce, if thou beest hungry, 〈◊〉 thou stay a month from meat? Nay, if I see my diet before me, I love to fall too when I have a stomach. Here, buy thee a new smock; let's have a new bed too, and look it be strong: there's a box of rings and jewels, lay them up. Ha sirrah; methinks the very name of wedlock hath brought me to a nightcap already, and I am grown civil on the sudden. There's more money for dishes, platters, ladles, candlesticks, etc. as I shall find them set down in the inventory.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: But whom shall we invite unto the wedding?
sp.stage: Enter 2d. Luce, a young country gentlewoman, in the habit of a page, and overheares their discourse.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Ay, thereby hangs a tale, we will have no more at our marriage, but myself, to say, I take thee Luce; thou to say, I luce take thee Robin: the vicar to put us together, and you father, to play the clerk, and cry amen.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Your reason for that.

sp.speaker: Chartl.
sp.p: I would not for a world it should be known to my friends, or come to my father's care. It may be ten thousand pounds out of my way for the present: therefore this is my conceit, let us be married privately, and Luce shall live like a maid still, and bear the name. 'tis nothing Luce: it is a common thing in this age to go for a maid, and be none. I'll frequent the house secretly: fear not girl, though I revel abroad a days, I'll be with thee to bring a nights, my little whiting mop.

lg.l: But so I may incur a public scandal,
By your so oft frequenting to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Scandal? what scandal? Why to stop the mouth of all scandal, after some few day's do I appear in my likeness, married man and honest housekeeper, and then what becomes of your scandal? Come, send for Mr. vicar, and what we do, let's do suddenly.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Cold comfort for me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: If you purpose to be so privately married, I know one excellent at such an exploit: are you not acquainted with the wise-woman of Hogsdon?

sp.speaker: Chartl●y.
sp.p: O the witch, the beldame, the hag of Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The same, but I hold her to be of no such condition. I will anon make a step thither ▪ and punctually acquaint her with all our proceedings: she is never without a sir John at her elbow, ready for such a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Well, be't so then.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Heigh ho: have I disguised myself, and stolen out of the country thus far, and can light of no better news to entertain me? O this wild-headed wicked Chartley, whom nothing will tame. To this gallant was I poor gentlewoman betrothed, and the marriage day appointed: but he out of a fantastic and
giddy humour, before the time prefixed, posts up to London. After him come I thus habited, and you see my welcome, to be an earwitness of his second contracting. Modesty would not suffer me to discover myself, otherwise, I should have gone near to have marred the match. I heard them talk of Hogsdon, and a wise-woman, where these aims shall be brought to action. I'll see if I can insinuate myself into her service: that's my next project: and now good luck of my side.

div.head: Actus secundus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the wise-woman and her clients, a countryman with an urinal, four women like citizens wives, Taber a servingman, and a chambermaid.

lg.l: Fie, fie, what a toil, and a moil it is,
For a woman to be wiser than all her neighbours?
I pray good people, press not too fast upon me;
Though I have two ears, I can hear but one at once.
You with the urine.

sp.speaker: Countryman.
sp.p: Here forsooth mistress.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And who distilled this water?

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.p: My wife's limbeck, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And where doth the pain hold her most?
Marry at her heart forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Ay, at hor heart, she hath a griping at her heart.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: You have hit it right.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Nay, I can see so much in the urine.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Just so much as is told her.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: She hath no pain in her head, hath she?
No indeed, I never heard her complain of her head.

lg.l: I told you so, her pain lies all at her heart:
Alas good heart! but how feels she her stomach?

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.p: O queasy, and sick at stomach.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Ay, I warrant you, I think I can see as far into a millstone as another: you have heard of mother Nottingham, who for her time, was prettily well skilled in casting of waters: and after her, mother Bomby; and then there is one Hatfield in Pepper-alley, he doth pretty well for a thing that's lost. There's another in Coleharbour, that's skilled in the planets. Mother Sturton in Goulden-lane, is for forespeaking: mother Phillips of the Bankside, for the weakness of the back: and then there's a very reverent matron on Clarkenwell-green, good at many things: mistress Mary on the bank - side, is for recting a figure: and one (What do you call her) in Westminster, that practiseth the book and the key, and the sieve and the shears: and all do well, according to their talon. For myself, let the world speak: hark you my friend, you shall take —

lg.l: 'Tis strange the ignorant should be thus fooled.
What can this witch, this wizard, or old trot,
Do by enchantment, or by magic spell?
Such as profess that art should be deep scholars.
What reading can this simple woman have?
'Tis palpable gross foolery.

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p: Now friend, your business?

lg.l: I have stolen out of my master's house, forsooth,
With the kitchenmaid, and I am come to know of you,
Whether it be my fortune to have her, or no.

sp.p: And what's your suit, lady?

sp.speaker: Kitchenmaid
sp.p: Forsooth, I come to know whether I be a maid or no.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Why, art thou in doubt of that?

sp.speaker: Kitchenmaid
sp.p: It may be I have more reason than all the world knows.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay, if thou comest to know whether thou beest a maid or no, I had best ask to know whether I be with child or no.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Withdraw into the parlour there, I'll but talk with this other gentlewoman, and he resolve you presently.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Come Sisty, if she cannot resolve thee, I can, and in the case of a maidenhead do more than she, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: The Wom.
sp.p: Forsooth I am bold, as they say.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You are welcome gentlewoman. —

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I would not have it known to my neighbours, that I come to a wise-woman for any thing, by my truly.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: For should your husband come and find you here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My husband woman, I am a widow.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Where are my brains? 'tis true, you are a widow; and you dwell, let me see, I can never remember that place.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: In Kentstreet.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Kentstreet, Kentstreet! and I can tell you wherefore you come.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why, and say true?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: You are a wag, you are a wag: why, what do you think now I would say?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Perhaps, to know how many husbands I should have.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: And if I should say so, should I say amiss?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I think you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: In, in, I'll but read a little of Ptolemy, and erra pater; and when I have cast a figure, I'll come to you presently.
Now wag, what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: If this were a wise-woman, she could tell that without asking. Now methinks I should come to know whether I were a boy or a girl; forsooth I lack a service.

sp.speaker: Wis●.
sp.p: By my fidelity, and I want a good trusty lad.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Now could I sigh, and say, alas, this is some bawd trade-fallen, and out of her wicked experience, is come to be reputed wise. I'll serve her, be't but to pry into the mystery of her science.

sp.speaker: Wis●.
sp.p: A proper stripling, and a wise, I warrant him; here's a penny for thee, I'll hire thee for a year by the statute of Winchester: prove true and honest, and thou shalt want nothing that a good boy —

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Here wise-woman you are out again, I shall want what a good boy should have ▪ whilst I live: well, here I shall live both unknown, and my sex unsuspected. But whom have we here?
sp.stage: Enter master Haringfield, and Chartley half drunk.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Come Haringfield, now we have been drinking of mother Redcap's ale, let us now go make some sport with the wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: We shall be thought very wise men, of all such as shall see us go in to the wise-woman's.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: See, here she is; how now witch? How now hag? How now beldame? You are the wise-woman, are you? and have wit to keep your self warm enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Out thou knave.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And will these wild oats never be sowed?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You enchantress, sorceress, she-devil ▪ you madam Hecate, lady Proserpine, you are too old, you hag, now, for conjuring up spirits yourself; but you keep pretty young witches under your roof, that can do that.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Ay, or my family conjure up any spirits! I defy thee, thou young harebrained —

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Forbear him till he have his senses about him, and I shall then hold thee for a wise-woman indeed. : otherwise, I shall doubt thou hast thy name for nothing. Come friend, away, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Away you old dromedary, I'll come one of these nights, and make a racket amongst your sheecatterwaullers.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: I prithee let's be civil.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou she-mastiff.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Patience, sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Now bless me, he hath put me into such a fear, as makes all my bones to dance, and rattle in my skin: I'll be revenged on that swaggering companion.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistress, I wish you would, he's a mere madcap, and all his delight is in misusing such reverent matrons as yourself.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Well, what's thy name, boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am even little better than a turn-broach, for my name is Jack.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Honest Jack, if thou couldst but devise how I might cry quittance with this cutting Dick, I will go near to adopt thee my son and heir.

lg.l: Mistress, there is a way, and this it is;
Tomorrow morning doth this gentleman
Intend to marry with one mistress luce,
A goldsmith's daughter; do you know the maid?
My daughter, and a pretty smug faced girl.
I had a note but late from her, and she means
To be with me in th'evening; for I have bespoke
Sir Boniface to marry her in the morning.
Do but prevent this gallant of his wife,
And then your wrongs shall be revenged at full.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I'll do't, as I am matron; ay, and show him a new trick for his learning.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: You're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Art wise?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: He should be wise, because he speaks few words.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I am as I am, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Canst conjure?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: O that's a foul word! but I can tell you your fortune, as they say; I have some little skill in palmistry, but never had to do with the devil.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: And had the devil never any thing to do with thee? thou lookest somewhat like his dam. Look on me canst tell what I ail?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Can you tell yourself? I should guess, you be mad, or not well in your wits.

lg.l: Thou'rt wise, I am so; men being in love, are mad,
And I being in love ▪ am so.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Nay, if I see your complexion once, I think I can guess as near as another.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: One mistress luce I love, knowest thou her, grannam?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: As well as the beggar knows his dish. Why she is one of my daughters.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Make her my wife, I'll give thee forty pieces.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Take them mistress, to be revenged on Chartley.

lg.l: A bargain, strike me luck, cease all your sorrow,
Fair luce shall be your bride betimes tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Th'art a good grannam; and, but that thy teeth stand like hedge-stakes in thy head, I'd kiss thee.

lg.l: Pray will you in; come hither lack, I have
A new trick come into my head, wilt thou
Assist me in't?
If it concern the crossing of the marriage with
Mistress Luce, I'll do't whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Thou shalt be 'tired like a woman; can you make a courtesy, take small strides, simper, and seem modest? methinks thou hast a woman's voice already.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Doubt not of me, th● act them naturally.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I have conceited, to have Luce married to this blunt gentleman; she mistaking him for Chartley, and Chartley shall marry thee, being a boy, and take thee for luce. Wilt not be excellent?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: O super, superexcellent!

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Play but thy part, as I'll act mine, I'll fit him with a wife, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And a wife I'll warrant him.
sp.stage: Exeunt. Enter old sir Harry, and his man taber.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ha, than thou sawest them whispering with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I saw them, if it shall please you, not whisper, but —

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: How then, thou knave?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Marry sir knight, I saw them in sad talk; but to say they were directly whispering, I am not able.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why taber, that sad talk was whispering.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay, they did not greatly whisper, for I heard what was said, and what was said, I have the wit to keep to myself.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: What said the unthrift, taber, tell me knave? Tell me, good knave, what did the unthrift say?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I am loath to be called in question about men and women's matters, but as soon as ever he saw your daughter, I heard what was spoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Here sirrah, take thy quarter's wages aforehand, and tell me all their words, and what their greeting was at their first encounter; hold thine hand.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Thanks, noble sir, and now I'll tell you. Your daughter being walking to take the air of the fields, and I before her; whom should we meet just in the nick?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Just in the nick, man?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: In the highway I meant, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ha, and what conference passed betwixt them, taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
As well as my pipe can utter, you shall know sir.
This gentleman meeting with my young mistress full butt; imagine you were she, and I young master Sencer; now there you come, and here I meet you; he comes in this manner, and put off his hat in this fashion.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ay, but what said he?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Be with you, fair gentlewoman; and so goes quite away, and scarce so much as once looked back: and if this were language to o●r to a young lady, judge you.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: But spoke he nothing else?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nothing as I am true.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why man, all this was nothing.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Yes sir, it was as much as my quarter's wages aforehand.
sp.stage: Enter master Sencer, master Haringfield, and Gratiana.

lg.l: Here are two gentlemen with great desire,
Crave conference with my father: here he is,
Now gallants, you may freely speak your minds.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Save you sir, my name is Sencer; I am a Northamptonshire gentleman, born to a thousand pound land by the year: I love your daughter, and I am come to crave your goodwill.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Have you my daughters, that you covet mine?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: No sir, but I hope in time I shall have.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: So hope not I. Sir, sir, my daughter's young, and you a gentleman unknown, Sencer? ha, Sencer? O sir, your name I now remember well, 'tis ranked 'mongst thrifts, dicers, swaggerers, and drunkards: were not you brought before me, some month since, for beating of the watch, by the same token, I sent you to the counter?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I confess myself to have been in that action, but note the cause, sir: you could not have pleasured me so much, in giving me a piece of gold, as at the same time to help me to that counter.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why sir, what cause had you to beat the watch, and raise a midnight tumult in the streets?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Nay, but hear me, sweet sir Harry: being somewhat late at supper at the mitre, the doors were shut at my lodging, I knocked at three or four places more, all were a-bed, and fast: inns, taverns, none would give me entertainment. Now, would you have had me despaired, and lain in the streets? No, I bethought me of a trick worth two of that, and presently devised, having at that time a charge of money about me, to be lodged, and safely too.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: As how, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Marry thus: I had knocked my heels against the ground a good while, knew not where to have a bed for love nor money. Now what did I? but spying the watch, went and hit the constable a good souse on the ear, who provided me of a lodging presently; and the next day, being brought before your worship, I was then sent thither back again, where I lay three or four days without control.

lg.l: O, you're a gallant! is that gentleman
A suitor too?
I am a suitor in my friend's behalf,
No otherwise: I can assure you, sir,
He is a gentleman descended well,
Derived from a good house, well qualified,
And well possessed; but that which most should move you,
He loves your daughter.
But were I to choose,
Which of these two should please my fancy best,
I sooner should affect this gentleman,
For his mad carriage, and his fair discourse,
Than my hot suitor; ruffians I detest:
A smooth and square behaviour likes me best.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: What say you to me, lady.

sp.speaker: Gratian.
sp.p: You had best ask my father what I should say.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Are you angry, sweet lady, that I asked your father's consent?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: No, if you can get his consent to marry him, shall it displease me?

lg.l: Indeed you therein much forget yourself,
To sound her father ere you tasted her.
You should have first sought means for her goodwill,
And after compassed his.
He can prevail with neither: gentlemen,
If you will come to revel, you are welcome;
If to my table, welcome; if to use me
In any grateful office, welcome too:
But if you come as suitors, there's the door.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: The door!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I say the door.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why sir? tell not me of your door, nor going out of it, your company is fair and good, and so is your daughters; I'll stay here this twelvemonth, ere I'll offer to trouble your door.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir, but you shall not. Taber! where's that knave?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why sir, I hope you do not mean to make us dance, that you call for a taber.

lg.l: Nay master Sencer, do not urge the knight,
He is incensed now, choose a fitter hour,
And tempt his love in that: old men are testy,
Their rage, if stood against, grows violent;
But suffered and forborn, confounds itself.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Where's Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: At hand, noble master.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Show them the door.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: That I will, and take money too, if it please them.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Is thy name Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I am so ecliped sir.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: And taber, are you appointed to give us Jack drum's entertainment?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Why sir, you do not play upon me.

sp.speaker: Se●er.
sp.p:
Though I cannot, yet I have known an hare
that could. But knight, thou dost not forbid us the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Yes, and forewarn it too.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: But by thy favour, we may choose whether we will take any warning or no. Well, farewell old knight, though thou forbidst me thine house, I'll honour thee, and extol thee; and though thou keepest me from thy daughter, thou shalt not hinder me to love her, and admire her: and by thy favour, sometimes to see her: a cat may look at a King, and so may I at her. Give me thine hand, knight, the next time I come into thy company, thou shalt not only bid me welcome, but hire me to stay with thee, and thy daughter.

lg.l: When I do that, enjoy my full consent,
To marry Graciana.
'Tis a match, strike me luck:
Wife that may be, farewell: father in law that
Must be, adieu. Taber, play before, my friend
And I will dance after.
When I receive thee gladly to mine house,
And wage thy stay, thou shalt have Gratiana,
Doubt not, thou shalt. Here's a strange humourist,
To come a-wooing . Taber, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I have played them away, if it please your worship ▪ and yonder at the door attends a schoolmaster, you sent for him, if you remember, to teach my little young master and mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: A proper scholar, pray him to come neare.
sp.stage: Enter a pedantical schoolmaster, sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Eques Honoratus: aue fulutatus: non video quid est in tergo, sed salve bona virgo.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir, you may call me nicknames: if you love me, speak in your mother-tongue; or at the least, if learning be so much allied unto you, that Latin unawares flows from your lips: to make your mind familiar with my knowledge, pray utter it in English: what's your name?

lg.l: Sit fanstum tibi omen.
I'll tell you my nomen.
Will you tell it to no men.
I'll entertain none ere I know their names:
Nay, if you be so dainty of your name,
You are not for my service.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Intend vir nobilis.

lg.l: Not for twenty nobles:
Trust me, I will not buy your name so dear.
O ignorantia! what it is to deal with stupidity?
Sir Henry, sir Henry, hear me one word,
I see, precepter legit, uos vero negligitis.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I think he saith we are a company of fools, and nigits, but I hope you shall not find us such, master schoolmaster.

lg.l: Friend, friend, to cut off all vain circumstance,
Tell me your name, and answer me directly,
Plainly, and to my understanding too,
Or I shall leave you: here's a deal of gibberish.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Vir bone.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Nay, nay, make me no bones, but do't.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Then in plain vulgar English I am called, sir Boniface Absee.

lg.l: Why this is somewhat like, sir Boniface,
Give me thine hand, thou art a proper man,
And in my judgement, a great scholar too:
What shall I give thee by the year?
I'll trust, sir, to your generosity;
I will not bargain, but account myself
Mille et mille modis, bound to you.
I cannot leave my mills, they're farmed already,
The stipend that I give, shall be in money.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sure sir, this is some miller that comes to undermine you, in the shape of a schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You both mistake the scholar.

lg.l: I understand my English, that I know;
What's more than modern, doth surpass my reach.
Sir Boniface, come to me two days hence,
You shall receive an answer; I have now,
Matters of some import that trouble me,
Thou shouldst be else dispatched.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, if you come to live in our house, and be a Familist amongst us, I shall desire you better acquaintance, your name and my phisnomy should have some consanguinity, good sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Quomodo vales, quomodo vales.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Go with you to the alehouse? I like the motion well; I'll make an excuse out of doors and follow you. I am glad yet, we shall have a goodfellow come into the house amongst us.

sp.speaker: Sir bonif.
sp.p: Vale vir magno.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: You shall not have me at saint Magnes, my house is here in Gracious-street.

lg.l: I know it, sweet knight, I know it.
Then virgo formosa, et dominae gratioso valete.
Ay, in Gracious-street you shall hear of me,
Sir Bonif. He shall instruct my children; and to thee,
Fair Gratiana, read the Latin tongue,

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Who, shall sir bawdy-face?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, you fool.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: His name is so hard to hit on.

lg.l: Come daughter, if things fall out as I intend,
My thoughts shall peace have, and these troubles end.

div.head: Actus tertius, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the second Luce, which was Jack in woman's apparel, and the wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Jack, thou art my boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistress!

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I'll be a mother to thee, no mistress: come lad, I must have thee sworn to the orders of my house, and the secrets thereof.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: As I am an honest lad, I am yours to command. But mistress, what mean all these women's pictures, hanged here in your withdrawing room?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: I'll tell thee, boy; marry thou must be secret. When any citizens, or young gentlemen come hither, under a colour to know their fortunes, they look upon these pictures, and which of them they best like, she is ready with a wet finger: here they have all the furniture belonging to a private-chamber, bed, bedfellow and all; but mum, thou knowest my meaning, Jack.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: But I see coming and going, maids, or such as go for maids, some of them, as if they were ready to lie down, sometimes two or three delivered in one night; then suddenly leave their brats behind them, and convey themselves into the city again: what becomes of their children?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Those be kitchenmaids, and chambermaids, and sometimes good men's daughters; who having catched a clap, and growing near their time, get leave to see their friends in the country, for a week or so: then hither they come, and for a matter of money, here they are delivered. I have a mid wife or two belonging to the house, and one sir Boniface a deacon, that makes a shift to christen the infants: we have poor, honest, and secret neighbours, that stand for common gossips. But dost not thou know this?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Yes, now I do: but what after becomes of the poor infants?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Why, in the night we send them abroad, and lay one at this man's door, and another at that, such as are able to keep them; and what after becomes of them, we inquire not. And this is another string to my bow.

lg.l: Most strange, that woman's brain should apprehend
Such law less, indirect, and horrid means
For covetous gain! How many unknown trades
women and men are free of, which they never
Had charter for? but mistress, are you so
Cunning as you make yourself: you can
Neither write nor read, what do you with hose
Books you so often turn over?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Why tell the leaves; for to be ignorant, and seem ignorant, what greater folly?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Believe me, this is a cunning woman; neither hath she her name for nothing, who out of her ignorance, can fool so many that think themselves wise. But wherefore have you built this little closet close to the door, where sitting, you may hear every word spoken, by all such as ask for you.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: True, and therefore I built it: if any knock, you must to the door and question them, to find what they come about, if to this purpose, or to that. Now they ignorantly telling thee their errand, which I sitting in my closet, over hear, presently come forth, and tell them the cause of their coming, with every word that hath passed betwixt you in private: which they admiring, and thinking it to be miraculous, by their report I become thus famous.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: This is no trade, but a mystery; and were I a wise-woman, as indeed I am but a foolish boy, I need not live by your service. But mistress, we lose ourselves in this discourse, is not this the morning in which I should be married?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Now, how had I forgotten myself? Mistress Luce promised to be with me half an hour ago, but masked and disguised, and so shalt thou be too: here's a black veil to hide thy face against the rest come.

sp.speaker: Sir bonif.
sp.p: Sit tibi bona dies: salus et quies.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Into the withdrawing room, sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Without any compunction, I will make the conjunction.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Now keep thy countenance, boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Fear not me, I have as good a face in a mask, as any lady in the land could wish to have: but to my heart, he comes, or he comes not; now am I in a pitiful perplxity, until I see the event of all.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: No more Jack now, but mistress Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I warrant you mistress: that it happens so luckily, that my name should be luce too, to make the marriage more firm!
sp.stage: Enter Chartley disguised, and in a wizard.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: My honey sweet hag, where's Luce?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Here sweet heart, but disguised and veiled, as you are vizarded.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But what's the reason we are thus hoodwinked?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: No discovery of yourselves for a million, there's sir Boniface within, shall he blab who you are? Besides, there's a young heir that hath stolen a lord's daughter from the court, and would not have their faces seen for a world: cannot you be content to fare well, and keep your own counsel, and see, yonder they come.
sp.stage: Enter at several places, Boyster vizarded, and Luce masked.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Gramercy my sugar-candy sweet trot.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Mum, no more words.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: If the great heir and the young lady be so dainty of their complexions, they shall see (My sweet luce) we can wizard it with the best of them.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: That gentleman, by the wise-woman's description, should be master Chartley. (Meaning Boyster.)

lg.l: That gallant wench, if my grannam fable not,
Should be luce: but what be those other?

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p:
You wrong me, but to ask, who but a young
heir, and a lady of the court: that's luce, take her, and keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Pocas palabras.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: That's Chartley, take him luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But who be they?

sp.speaker: Taber

lg.l: A lord and lady shall sir Boniface stay,
Rather than so, strive who should lead the way.

sp.stage: Exeunt Chartley with Jack, Boyster with Luce.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p: Now Jack my boy, keep thine own counsel, and countenance, and I shall cry quittance with my young gallant. Well, by this time sir Boniface is at his book. But because there is a mistake, known only to my boy and myself; the marriage shall be no sooner ended, but I'll disturb them by some sudden outcry, and that too, before they have leisure to unmask, and make known themselves one to another; for if the deceit were known, I should fall into the danger of that young mad rascal. And now this double apprehension of the lord and the lady shall fetch me off from all; I know it is sir Boniface his custom, to make short work, and hath dispatched by this: and now wise-woman, try if thou canst bestir thyself like to a madwoman — shift for yourselves, warrants and pursuivants! Away, warrants and pursuivants! shift for yourselves.
sp.stage: Enter, as affrighted and amazed, Chartley, Boyster, Boniface, and others.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I'll take this way.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I this.

lg.l: Curro curris curcurri: my cheeks are all murry,
And I am gone in an hurry.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O heaven! what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I know what shall become of me already.

sp.speaker: Taber
sp.p:
O sweet daughter, shift clothes with this
lady! Nay, as thou lovest thy credit and mine, change habits — so, if thou beest taken in her garments, finding the mistake, will let thee pass; and should they meet her in thine, not knowing her, would no way question her: and this prove to both your securities and my safety.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: As fast as I can, good mother: so madam farewell.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: All happy joys betide you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Ha, ha, let me hold my sides, and laugh: here were even a plot to make a play on, but that Chartley is so fooled by my boy Jack: well, he'll make a notable wag, I'll warrant him. All the jest will be, if Boyster should meet with him in Luce's habit, which he hath now on, he would think himself merely gulled and cheated; and should Chartley meet with luce as she is now robed, he would be confident he had married her. Let me see how many trades have I to live by: first, I am a wise-woman, and a fortune-teller, and under that I deal in physic and fore-speaking, in palmistry, and recovering of things lost. Next, I undertake to cure mad folks. Then I keep gentlewomen lodgers, to furnish such chambers as I let out by the night: then I am provided for bringing young wenches to bed; and for a need, you see I can play the matchmaker. She that is but one, and professeth so many, may well be termed a wise-woman, if there be any.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Why, run away, and leave my wench behind? I'll back: what have warrants and pursuivants to do with me? with me? why should I budge? why should I wear mask or wizard? If lords or ladies offend, let lords and ladies answer; let me better bethink me. Why should I play at hob-man blind? Hum; why marry in tenebris, ha! is there no trick in it? If my
grannam should make me a younger brother now, and instead of Luce, pop me off with some broken commodity, I were finely served: most sure I am, to be in for better and worse, but with whom, heaven and my grannam knows.
sp.stage: Enter half ready and masked, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am stolen out of doors, to see if I can meet my husband; with whom I purpose to make some sport, ere I suddenly disclose myself: what's he?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Heyday, what have we here, an hoberdehoy? come hither you.

lg.l: 'Tis mistress Luce's husband,
I'll not leave him thus.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: That mask and robe I know?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I hope so, or else I were in a woe case.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: That mask, that gown I married.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Then you have no reason, but to enjoy both them and me too, and so you are like; I should be loath to divorce man and wife.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I am fooled, but what cracked ware are you, forsooth?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I belong to the old gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I'll set her house on fire: I am finely bobbed.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: But I hope you will not bob me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: No I'se warrant thee: what art thou? Girl or boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Both, and neither; I was a lad last night, but in the morning I was conjured into a lass: and being a girl now, I shall be translated to a boy anon. Here's all I can at this time say for myself: farewell.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Yes, and be hanged withal. O for some gun
powder to blow up this witch, this she-male, this damned sorceress! O I could tear her to fitters with my teeth! Yet I must be patient, and put up all, lest I be made a jeer to such as know me: fooled by a boy! Go too, of all the rest, the girl Luce must not know it.
sp.stage: Enter Chartley and his man, meeting Luce.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: So, now am I the same man I was yesterday; who can say I was disguised? or who can distinguish my condition now? or read in my face, whether I be a married man, or a bachelor?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sweet husband, is it you?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The news?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Never so frighted in my days.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What's become of the lord and the lady?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The lord fled after you, the lady stayed; who masked, and half unready, ran fast after her poor affrighted husband: now all's quiet.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: This storm is then well passed, and now convey yourself home as privately as you can: and see you make this known to none but your father.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I am your wife and servant.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: This name of Luce hath been ominous to me; one Luce I should have married in the country, and just the night before, a toy took me in the head, and mounting my horse, I left capons, ducks, geese, poultry, wild-fowl, father, and bride and all, and posted up to London, where I have ever since continued bachelor, till ▪ now. And now —

div.stage: Enter Gratiana in haste, a servingman before her, and taber after her.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Nay on, I prithee fellow on, my father will wonder where I have been visiting. Now, what had I forgotten? Taber, there's money, go to the goldsmiths, bid him send me my fan; and make a quick return: on, fellow on.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Her fan at the goldsmiths! now had I forgotten to ask her his name, or his sign: but I will after to know.

lg.l: Sirrah, go call me back that servingman,
And ask him what's the gentlewoman's name.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I shall; ho, you: friend, you.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Who's that calls?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: 'Twas I.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Your business? you should be one, though not of my cognisance, yet of my condition: a serving-creature, as I take it: pray what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Pray sir, what might I call that gentlewoman, on whom you were attendant?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: You may call her what you please, but if you call her otherwise than in the way of honesty, you may perchance hear on't.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Nay, be not offended: I say, what do you call her?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Why sir, I call her as it shall best please me, sometimes young lady, sometimes young mistress; and what hath any man to do with that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Are you so captious, sirrah, what's her name? Speak, and be brief.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Ay marry sir, you speak to purpose, and I can resolve you: her name is Gratiana. But all this while I have forgotten my mistress fan.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Gratiana! oft have I heard of her, but saw her
not till now: 'tis a pretty wench, a very pretty wench, nay, a very, very, very pretty wench. But what a rogue am I, of a married man? nay, that have not been married this six hours, and to have my shittle-wits run a woolgathering already? What would poor Luce say if she should hear of this? I may very well call her poor luce, for I cannot presume of five pounds to her portion: what a coxcomb was I, being a gentleman, and well derived, to match into so beggarly a kindred? What needed I to have grafted in the stock of such a choke pear, and such a goodly poppering as this to escape me? Escape me (Said I?) if she do, she shall do it narrowly: but I am married already, and therefore it is not possible, unless I should make away my wife, to compass her. Married! why who knows it? I'll outface though priest, and then there is none but she and her father, and their evidence is not good in law: and if they put me in suit, the best is, they are poor, and cannot follow it. I marry sir, a man may have some credit by such a wife as this; I could like this marriage well, if a man might change away his wife, still as he is a weary of her, and cope her away like a bad commodity: if every new moon a man might have a new wife, that's every year a dozen. But this, till death us depart, is tedious: I will go a-wooing to her, I will; but how shall I do for jewels and tokens? Luce hath mine in her custody, money and all; tush, I'll juggle them from her well enough: see, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Here is my husband, I pray move him in it.

lg.l: It toucheth both our reputations nearly;
For by his oft repair, now whilst the marriage
Is kept from public knowledge, your good name
may be by neighbours hardly censured of.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Thou'rt sad, thou'rt sad Luce what, melancholy already ▪ ●re thou hast had good cause to be merry, and know'st what sport was.

lg.l: I have great reason, when my name is tossed
In every gossip's mouth, and maded a byword
Unto such people as it least concerns.
Nay, in my hearing, as they pass along,
Some have not spared to brand my modesty,
Saying, there sits she whom young Chartley keeps.
There hath ●ee entered late, betimes gone forth.
Where I with pride was wont to sit before,
I'm now with shame sent blushing from the door.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Alas poor fool, I am sorry for thee, but yet cannot help thee, as I am a gentleman. Why say Luce, thou losest now forty shillings worth of credit, stay but a time, and it shall bring thee in a thousand pounds worth of commodity.

lg.l: Son, son, had I esteemed my profit more
Than I have done my credit, I had now
Been many thousands richer: but you see,
Truth and good dealing bear an humble sail;
That little I enjoy, it is with quiet,
Got with good conscience, kept with good report:
And that I still shall labour to preserve.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But do you hear me?

lg.l: Nothing I'll hear, that tends unto the ruin
Of mine, or of my daughter's honesty.
Shall I be held a broker to lewd lust,
Now in my wane of years?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Will you but hear me?

lg.l: Not in this case. I that have lived thus long,
Reported well, esteemed a welcome guest
At every burdened table, there respected;
Now to be held a pander to my daughter?
That I should live to this 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But hark you father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: A bawd to mine own child ▪

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: To my sweet Luce!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father?

lg.l: Deal with me like a son, then call me father;
I that have had the tongues of every man
Ready to crown my reputation:
The hands of all my neighbours to subscribe
To my good like; and such as could not write,
Ready with palsy and unlettered fingers,
To set their scribbling marks.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why father in law?

lg.l: Thou hadst a mother Luce; 'tis woe with me
To say thou hadst, but haste not; a kind wife,
And a good nurse she was: she, had she lived
To hear my name thus canvased, and thus tossed,
Seven years before she died, I had been a widower
Seven years before I was: heaven rest her soul,
She is in heaven I hope.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why so now, these be good words, I knew these storms would have a shower, and then they would cease. Now if your anger be over, hear me.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Well, say on son.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Stay but a month, 'tis but four weeks; nay, 'tis February, the shortest month of the year, and in that time I shall be at full age; and the land being entailed, my father can disinherit me of nothing. Is your spleen down now have I satisfied you? Well, I see you choleric hasty men, are the kindest when all is done. Here's such wetting of handkerchers, he weeps to think of his wife, she weeps to see her father cry ▪ peace fool, we shall else have thee claim kindred of the woman killed with kindness.

lg.l: Well son, my anger's past; yet I must tell you,
It grieves me that you should thus slight it off,
Concerning us, no such a dear degree.
In private be it spoke, my daughter tells me,
She's both a wife and maid.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That may be helped.

Now Luce, your fathers pacified, will you be pleased? I would endure a quarter's punishment for thee, and wilt not thou suffer a poor months penance for me? 'tis but eight and twenty days, wench; thou shalt fare well all the time, drink well, eat well, lie well: come, one word of comfort at the later end of the day.

lg.l: Yours is my fame, mine honour, and my heart
Linked to your pleasure, and shall never part.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Gramercy wench, thou shalt wear this chain no longer for that word, I'll multiply the links in such order, that it shall have light to shine about thy neck, oftener than it doth: this jewel, a plain Bristol stone, a counterfeit. How base was I, that coming to thee in the way of marriage, courted thee with counterfeit stones? Thou shalt wear right, or none: thou hast no money about thee, luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have the hundred pounds that you gave me to lay up last.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Fetch it; let me see, how much branched satin goes to a petticoat? and how much wrought velvet to a gown? then for a beaver for the city, and a blackbag for the country: I'll promise her nothing, but if any such trifles be brought home, let her not thank me for them.
Gramercy Luce, nay, go in, gravity and modesty, ten to one but you shall hear of me, ere you see me again.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
I know you kind, impute my hasty language
unto my rage, not me.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why, do not I know you, and do not I know her? I doubt you'll wish shortly that I had never known either of you: now, what sayst thou, my sweet luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My words are yours. so is my life: I am now part of yourself, so made by nuptial vows.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What a pagan am I, to practise such villainy against this honest christian! If Gratiana did come into my thoughts, I should fall into a vain to pity her: but now that I talk of her, I have a tongue to ▪ woo her, tokens to win her; and that done, if I do not find a trick, both to wear her, and weary her, it may prove a piece of a wonder. Thou seest, Luce, I have some store of crowns about me, there are brave things to be bought in the city; Cheapside, and the exchange, afford variety and rarity. This is all I will say now, but thou mayest hear more of me hereafter.

lg.l: Heaven speed you where you go sir; shall we in?
Though not from scandal, we live free from sin.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I'll in before.

lg.l: I am still in love with Luce, and I would know
An answer more directly: fie, fie, this love
Hangs on me like an ague, makes me turn fool ▪
Coxcomb and ass: why should I love her, why?
A rattle-baby, puppet, a slight toy,
And now I could go to buffets with myself,
And cuff this love away: but see, that's luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot shun him, but I'll shake him off.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: As much to you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I'll use few words, canst love me?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Deed sir no.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Why the farewell, the way I came, I'll go.

lg.l: This is no tedious courtship, he's soon answered,
So should all suitors else be, were they wise;
For being repulsed, they do but waste their days
In thankless suits, and superficial praise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Swear that thou wilt not love me.

lg.l: Not sir, for any hate I ever bore you,
Or any foolish pride, or vain conceit:
Or that your feature doth not please mine eye,
Or that you are not a brave gentleman:
But for concealed reasons I am forced
To give you this cold answer; and to swear
I must not, then with patience pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Even farewell then.

lg.l: The like to you, and save your hopes in me.
Heaven grant you your best wishes; all this strife
Will end itself, when I am known a wife.

div.head: Actus 4us. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter sir Harry, m. Harringsfield Gratiana with others.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am satisfied good m. Harringsfield touching your friend, and since I see you have left his dangerous company, I limit you to be a welcome guest unto my table.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: You have been always noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Taber: the news with thee?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: May it please the right worshipful to understand that there are some at the gate who dance a turn or two without, and desire to be admitted to speak with you within.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: The scholar is it not.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay sir, there are two scholars, and they are spouting latin one against the other; and in my simple judgement the stranger is the better scholar, and is somewhat too hard for sir Boniface: for he speaks louder, and that you know is ever the sign of the most learning, and he also hath a great desire to serve your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Two scholars; my house hath not place for two, thus it shall be. Taber admit them both, we though unlearned will hear them two dispute, and he that of the two seems the best read, shall be received, the other quite cashiered.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: In that you show but justice, in all persons merit should be regarded.
sp.stage: Enter taber ushering sir Boniface and Sencer, disguised like a pedant.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Venerabilis magistri: absint vobis capistri.

lg.l: Et tu domini calve, iterum atque, iterum salve,
Amo amas amavi, sweet lady heaven save ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: This approves him to be excellent, but I thank my breeding I understand not a word, you tongue-men you whose wealth lies in your brains; not in your budgets hear me: be it known, my house affords room for one schoolmaster but not for more. And I am thus resolved, take you that side gentle sir Boniface, and sir possess you that.
He of you two in arguing proves the best. To him will I subscribe are you agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nec animo, nec cord, nec utroque.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: No more of that nec cord, noble knight, he wishes you nec cord, think of that.

lg.l: A cord about my neck, sir Boniface.
Speak do you use me well.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Dominae currogas:

lg.l: Is this to be endured, to call a knight.
Cur, rogue and ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I find myself abused.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Yet patience good sir Harry, and hear more pray sir Boniface: of what university? Were you of.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I was student in brazen nose.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: A man might guess so much by your pimples, and of what place were you:

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Petrus dormit securus; I was sir of Peter house sir Boniface. Natus eram, in Woxford, and I proceeded in Oxford.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Est mihi bene nostrum, thou wouldst say, in Gotam; for my part sir Harry, I can read service and marry, que genus et flexum, though I go in genes fustian, scalpellum et charta I was not brought up at plough and cart, I can teach qui mihi, and neither laugh nor tee-hee, said as in present, if your worship at this present, iste, ista istud, will do me any good, to give me legem pone in
gold or in money. Piper atque papaver, I'll deserve it with my labour.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: But when go you to dispute.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nomnativo hic prediculus, his words are most ridiculous: but tu thou, qui the which, deridest those that be rich, consterve hanc sententiam, construe me this sentence. Est modus in rebus sunt certi denique fines:

lg.l: Est modus in rebus: there is mud in the rivers.
Sunt certi denique fines, and certain little fishes.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I warrant you he hath his answer ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Dij boni boni.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: He'll give you more bones than those to know on sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Kartere moosotropos poluphiltate phile poetatis taes logikes retoon, onch elashiste sophoon.

That is as much as to say, in our materna lingua I will make you sir Boniface, confess yourself an ass in English, speak open and broad words, for want of Latin, and denique instruct me to resolve such questions as I shall ask you in our modern tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Confess him an ass, speak obscene words after entreat thee to resolve thy questions. Do that, possess the place.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Di do and dumb: no more words but mum:

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Noble sir harry; nunquam sic possit?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir Boniface is sick already and calls for a possit, no marvel, being so threatened.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: You Boniface, decline me I am a no after the first conjugation, amo amavi, vocito vocitavi. Titubo titubavi?

lg.l: I am not the preceptor to a pupil.
But can decline it, mark sir Timothy:
I am a no,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Bene bene.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I am an as?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Most true most true, vos estis, ut egojum testes,
that what he confessed is, as true as the pestis.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: This scholar works by magic he hath made him confess himself an ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Per has meas manus vir, tues insanus,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I'll make him fret worse yet; sir Boniface: quid est grammatica.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Grammatica est ars,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Fie, fie, no more of these words good sir Boniface.

lg.l: Attend again, proceed me with this verse
Of reverent Cato: si deus est animus -

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nobis ut carmina dicunt.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Di quoth ha, out on him for a beastly man.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I would not have him teach my children so for more than I am worth.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: O! but reverend sir harry you must subaudi.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I'll never be so bawdy whilst I live, nor any of mine I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: O! propria quae maribus:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: ●y Boniface, it is those maribones, that makes you talk so broadly?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Venerabilis vir homo ille est ebrius.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What doth he mean by that.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: He saith, I can speak hebrew

lg.l: I believe't:
But if sir Boniface still con these lessons,
He'll, speak the French tongue perfect.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Now to the last, I'll task sir Boniface, but with an easy question. Tell me sir: what's latin for this earth?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Facile and easy more fit for the pupil than the preceptor: what's latin for this earth? Tellus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Tell you; no sir, it belongs to you to tell me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I say Tellus is Latin for the earth.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: And I say, I will not tell you what is Latin for the earth; unless you yield me victor ▪

lg.l: You have no reason: good sir Timothy,
The place is yours.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: He hath deserved it well.

lg.l: But I'll deserve it better, why this fellow
Is frantic, you shall hear me make him speak
Idly and without sense. I'll make him say,
His nose was husband to a Queen,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir Timothy not possible.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: He will not speak it for shame.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That you shall here; magister Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Quid ais dominae Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Who was Pasiphae's husband Queen of Crete.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Who knows not that, why Minos was her husband.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That his nose was; did I not tell you so.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I say that Minos was:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That his nose was ha has.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I'll not believe it.

lg.l: There are a brace of angels.
You are not for my turn sir Timothy.
You are the man shall read unto my daughter
The Latin tongue, in which I am ignorant:
Confess yourself an ass; speak bawdy words;
And after to talk idly. Hence away:
You shall have my good word, but not my pay?
Opus est usus; sir Timothy you abuse us.
Is wear by a noun, had I thy hose down,
Qui que quod, I would so smoke thee with the rod:
Ille illa illud, until I fetch blood.
But nobiles valete, remain in quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.

lg.l: Sir Timothy, there is some gold in earnest,
I like you well take into your tuition,

sp.p: My daughter Gratiana; the news taber.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Of another gallant noble sir that pretends to have business, both with you and my mistress,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Admit him.

div.stage: Enter Chartly very gallant, in his hand a lady.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Lusty juventus; will it please you to draw near.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Noble knight, whilst you peruse that sweet lady, tell me how you like this:

lg.l: You press so suddenly upon me sir
I know not what to answer.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Mad Chartly; what makes desperation here.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: To the word wooer let me add the name speeder my father hath written to your father, and the cause of his writing at this present, is to let you understand, that he fears you have lived a maid too long: and therefore to prevent all diseases incident to the same; as the green sickness and others. He sent me like a skilful physician, to take order with you against all such maladies. If you will not credit me, list but how fervently my father writes in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He is my only son, and she I take as your only daughter, what should hinder then,
To make a match between them, (Well 'tis well 'tis good I like it) I will make her jointure three hundred pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: How say you by that sweet lady three hundred pounds a year and a proper man to boot.

lg.l: All's good, I like it, welcome m. Chartly.
Thou Gratiana art no child of mine
Unless thou bidst him welcome. This I presume
To be your father's hand.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But I'll be sworn he never writ it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And this his seal at arms.

lg.l: Or else I understand it very poorly, but lady ▪
In earnest of further acquaintance, receive this chain,
These jewels, hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Refase no chain nor jewels, heart nor hand, but in exchange of these bestow thyself thine own dear self upon him.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p: Myself on him, whom I tell now I ne'er saw? Well since I must, your will's to me a law.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis time to speak, shall I stand here waiting like a coxcomb, and see her given away before my face? stay your hand sir harry; and let me claim my promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My promise I'll perform sir Timothy, you shall have all your wages duly paid.

lg.l: I claim fair Gratiana by your promise.
No more sir Timothy, but Sencer now,
You promised me when you received my service,
And with your liberal hand did wage my stay:
To endow me freely with your daughter's love,
That promise now I claim.
Mere cozenage, knavery,
I tide myself to no conditions.
In which such guile is practised, come son Chartly,
To cut of all disasters incident.
To these proceedings we will solemnize
These nuptial rites with all speed possible.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Farewell good sir Timothy; farewell learned sir Timothy.

lg.l: Why: and farewell learned sir Timothy.
For now sir Timothy and I are two:
Boast on, brag on, exalt exalt thyself,
Swim in a sea of pleasure and content
Whilst my bark suffers wrack I'll be revenged,
Chartly; I'll cry vindicta for this horn,
Next time thou gorest, it must be with thy horn,
I am mad, and know not at what.
I could swagger but know not with whom,
I am at odds with myself; and know not why:
I shall be pacified, and cannot tell when,
I would fain have a wife but cannot tell where,
I would fasten on luce but cannot tell how.
How; where; when; why; whom; what.
Feeding sure makes me lean, and fasting fat.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Not all this while once see me.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: His occasions, perhaps enforce his absence.

lg.l: His occasions:
Unless he find occasion of new love.
What could enforce such absence from his spouse:
Am I grown foul and black, since my espousals.
It should not seem so; for the shop is daily,
Customed with store of chapmen, such as come
To cheapen love. O no, I am myself?
But Chartly he is changed.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: You know that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Escape him if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: He cannot, I arrest you;

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: At whose suit.

lg.l: Not at mine own, that's dashed, I love thee not.
Thou art a Spaniard, Gipsy, a mere blackamoor:
Again, I say I love thee not.
A blackamoor, a Gipsy?
Sure I am changed indeed, and that's the cause
My husband left me so, this gentleman
Once termed me beautiful, how look I Joseph.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: As well as ere you did, fat, fresh, and fair ▪

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: You lie boy, pocket that, and now be gone.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: And what shall then become of my mistress ▪

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your mistress.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I know you will not wait on such a Gipsy.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes Luce on such a Gipsy: boy, abi abi.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: Abide fir, you need not fear that I have no purpose to leave her.

lg.l: Now you are going to the wedding-house.
You are bid to be a bride maid, are you not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What wedding sir, or whose?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Why Chartley's; Luce hath he been thy friend so long, and would not bid thee to write on his bride. Why lookest thou red and pale, and both, and neither.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: To Mr. Chartley's bridals, why, to whom, should he be married.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: To grace of gracious street.

lg.l: To Gratiana?
Beshrow you sir you do not use me well,
To buzz into mine ears these strange untruths:
I tell you sir, 'tis as impossible
That they two should match: as earth and heaven to meet.

sp.speaker: Boyster.

lg.l: You'll not believe it, pray then hark within,
The nuptial music echoing to their joys.
But you give credit to no certainties:
I told you but a tale, a lie, a fable?
A monstrous, a notorious idle untruth,
That you were black, and that I loved you not.
And you could credit that.

sp.stage: Enter sir Harry and haringsfield, Chartly leading Gratiana by the arm, taber and attendants.

lg.l: Who's telltruth now.
Know you that man, or know you that fine virgin:
Whom by the arm he leads.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I'll not endure't: heaven give you joy sir:

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I thank you: Luce?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Look to the maid she faints.

lg.l: Grace, come not near her grace.
Father keep off, on gentlemen apace.
Shees troubled with the falling sickness, for
Oft hath she fallen before me.
Nay if it be no otherwise, on gentlemen.
Let those with her strive to recover her.
Keep off, the disease is infectious:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: If it were in a man, it were nothing, but the falling sickness in a woman is dangerous.
My tother father in law, now shall I be utterly shamed, if he assure to know me, I'll out face him.
