sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Son your well met.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: How fellow.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Chart
sp.p: No harm done friend, no harm done.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: If he? he could not but have known me there, yet he was wondrous like him.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: How cheer you luce, whence grew this passion.

lg.l: Pardon me sir, I do not know myself:
I am apt to swoon, and now the fit is passed me.
I thank you for your help; is master Chartly
Vanished so soon:

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes: and to supply his place, see where thy father comes.

lg.l: He hath not such a suit, besides this gallant
Led by the arm a bride, a lusty bride?
How much might I have wronged the gentleman.
By craving his acquaintance, this it is,
To have dim eyes. Why looks my daughter sad.
I cry you mercy. Sir I saw not you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I would I had not seen you at this time neither, farewell.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: If he be gone? then call me vent my grief, ▪ father I am undone,

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Forbid it heaven.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Disgraced, despised, discarded, and cast off.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: How, mine own child:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My husband, oh my husband?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What of him.

lg.l: Shall I the shower of all my grief at once
Power out before you: Chartly, once my husband
Hath left me to my shame. Him and his bride,
I met within few minutes.
Sure was they.
I met them two, was he; base villain Jew.
I'll to the wedding board, and tell him so:
I'll do't as I am a man?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Be not so rash.

lg.l: I'll live and die upon him;
He's a base fellow, so I'll prove him too.
Joseph my sword.
This rashness will undo us.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I'll have my sword.

lg.l: It hath been twice in France, and once in Spain,
With John a gaunt, when I was young like him
I had my wards, and foins, and quarter-blows:
And knew the way into st. George's fields.
Twice in a morning, Tuttle, Finsbury?
I knew them all, I'll too him, where's my sword,
Or leave this spleen, or you will overthrow
Our fortunes quite, let us consult together,
What we were best to do.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I'll make him play at leapfrog, well I hear thee

lg.l: I cannot prove our marriage, it was secret,
And he may find some cavil in the law.
I'll too him with no law, but Staffood law.
I'll ferret the false boy, nay on good luce.
Part of your spleen, if you would change to counsel,
We might revenge us better.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Well I hear thee.

lg.l: To claim a public marriage at his hands:
We want sufficient proof, and then the world
Will but deride our folly, and so add
Double disgrace unto my former wrong.
To law with him he hath a greater purse,
And nobler friends, how then to make it known?
Is this his damasked kirtle fringe with gold,
His black bag, and his beaner, 'tis well yet
I have a sword:
And I have a project in my brain begot,
To make his own mouth witness to the world
My innocence, and his incontinence?
Leave it to me, I'll clear myself from blame,
Though I the wrong, yet he shall reap the shame.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Now or never, look about thee Sencer, tomorrow is the marriage day which to prevent, ly● not within the compass of my apprehension, therefore I have thus disguised myself, to go to thee, looming woman's, the fortune tellers. The any thing, the nothing, this over against mother Redcap's is her house, I'll knock.
sp.stage: Enter 〈◊〉. Luce in her boy's shape.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Who's there? What would you have.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I would speak with the wise gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: O belike you have lost somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: You are in the wrong sweet youth.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am somewhat thick of hearing, pray speak out.

lg.l: I say I have not lost any thing, but wit and time,
And neither of those she can help me too:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: The● you belike are cro● in love, and come to know what success you shall have.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it sweet lad; thou hast hit it.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: What is it, you say sir:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast ●it it?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I pray come in, I'll bring you to my mistress ▪

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: This is the house, knock Joseph, my business craves dispatch.

sp.speaker: Joseph.
sp.p: Now am I as angry, as thou art timorous, and now to vent the next thing I meet, oh 'tis the door.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Who's there, what are you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: A maid and a wife.

lg.l: And that would grieve any wench to be so,
I know that by myself, not luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Boy, where's your mistress.

lg.l: In some private talk with a gentleman?
I'll fetch her to you presently.
If she and you see me not, I am but dead,
I shall be made, a byword to the world:
The scorn of women; and my father's shame:

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: You tell me your name is Sencer, I knew it before, and that Chartly is to be married, I could have told it you.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Married tomorrow, oh me!

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Ay but you tell me, that Chartly before tomorrow shall be disappointed of his, make that good, thou shalt have twenty angels.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I'll do't, stand aside, I'll have but a word or two with this gentlewoman; and I am for you presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O! mother, mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
My husband marry another wife tomorrow? O changeable destiny, no sooner married to him, but instantly to lose him. Nor death it grieves me so much that I am a wife, but that I am a maid too, to carry one of them
well is as much as any is bound to do, but to be tied to both, is more than flesh and blood can endure.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Well trust to me, and I will sell all things straight.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Where's this witch, this hag, this beldame, this wizard, and have I found thee, thus then will I tear, mumble and maul thee.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Help, help, and if you be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Forbear this rudeness, he that touches her, draws against me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Against you sir, apply thou, that shall be tried.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Help, help, part them help.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: With patience hear her speak.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Now Trot, now Granam, what canst thou say for thyself: what luce hear be patient and put up them, she must not see the end.

lg.l: Than trince of all sides, if we come for counsel,
Let us with patience hear it:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Then first to me.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You would prevent young Chartley's marriage, you shall: hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It pleaseth me.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You forestall Gratiana's wedding, 'tis but thus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I'll do't,

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You would enjoy luce as your wife, and lie with her tomorrow night. Hark in your care.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Fiat.

lg.l: Away, you shall enjoy him, you are married,
Luce away, you shall see Chartly discarded from Gratiana,
Sencer be gone, and if I fail in any of these or the rest,
I lay myself open to all your displeasures.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Farewell till soon:

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: You know your meeting place.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We do?

sp.speaker: Wise-woman.
sp.p: You shall report me wiser and cunning too.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.

lg.l: I'll add one night more to the time, I have said.
I have not many I hope to live a maid.

sp.stage: Enter taber and sir Boniface with a trencher, with broken meat and a napkin.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what a time of trouble is this tomorrow tomorrow is my mistress to be married, and we serving-men are so puzzled.

lg.l: The dinner's half done, and before I say
Grace, and bid the old knight and his guest proface.
A medicine from your trencher, good m. taber.
As good a man as ere was sir Saber:
Well think it no shame, men of learning and wit, say study gets a stomach, friend Taber a bit.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Lick clean good sir Boniface, and save the scraper a labour.

lg.l: But soft let me ponder:
Know you him that comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Most heartily welcome, would you speak with any here.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Pray is the young gentleman of the house at leisure ▪

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Mean you the bridegroom m. Chartly.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I have a letter for him. You seem to be a gentleman yourself, acquaint him with my attendance, and I shall rest yours in all good offices.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, pray keep the gentleman company I will first acquaint your lips with the virtue of the seller.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Adesdem come near, and taste of your beer. Welcome, sine dole, for puntis te vole,

sp.speaker: Sencer.

lg.l: When I taste of your liquor.
Gramercy master vicar.

sp.stage: Enter taber with a bowl of beer and a napkine.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Most heartily welcome: your courtesy I beseech you, ply it off I entreat you, pray sir Boniface keep the gentleman company; till I acquaint my young master with his business.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Taber, I shall besolas manus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A vostre servitor.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: He what art thou,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A hanger on, if it please you:

sp.speaker: Harring.

lg.l: And I a shaker off, I'll not bear your gallows,
You shall not hang on me.

sp.stage: Enter Chartly with his napkin as from Dinner.
sp.p: O. Mr. bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the ladies call upon you to dance, they will be out of measure displeased, if dinner being done, you be not ready to lead them a measure:

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Indeed women love not to be scanted of their measure.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Fie sir Boniface: have you forgotten yourself, whilst you are in the hall, there's never a whetstone for their wits in the parlour?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I will enter and set an edge upon their ingenies.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: To me sir, from whom? A letter to her most dear, most loving, most kind friend Mr. Chartly these be delivered: sure from some wench or other I long to know the contents.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Now to cry quittance with you for my farewell learned sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Good news, as I live, there's for thy pains my good sir Pandarus: hadst thou brought me word my father had turned up his heels. Thou couldst scarcely have pleased me better: (He reads) though I disclaim the name of wife, of which I account myself altogether unworthy, yet let me claim some small interest in your love, this night I lie at the house where we were married, (The wise-woman's I mean) where my maidenhead is to be rifled, bid fair for it, and enjoy it, see me this night or never, so may you marrying Gratiana, and loving me, have a sweet wife and a true friend: this night or never, your quondam wife: hereafter your poor sweetheart no other: Luce. So when I am tired with Gratiana, that is when I am past grace. With her I can make my rendezvous, I'll not slip this occasion, nor sleep till I see her, thou art an honest lad, and mayst prove a good pimp in time. Canst thou advise me what colour, I may have to compass this commodity.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Sir, she this night expects you, and prepares a costly banquet for you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: I'll go, although the devil and mischance look big,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Feign some news that such a piece of land is fallen to you, and you must instantly ride to take possession of it, or which is more probable, cannot you persuade them you have received a letter that your father lies a dying.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: You rogue, I would he did but the name of that news is called, too good to be true.

sp.speaker: Sencer
sp.p: And that if ever you will see him alive, you must ride post into the country.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Enough: if ever I prove knight errant thou shalt be mine own proper squire, for this thou hast fitted me with a plot, do but wait here note how I will manage it,
Tabor my horse, for I must ride tonight ▪

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: tonight sir.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: So tell my bride and father, I have news that quite confounds my senses.
sp.stage: Enter sir Harry, Gratiana and Harringsfield.

lg.l: How ride tonight , the marriage day tomorrow
And all things well provided for the feast.
O tell me sweet, why do you look so pale.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: My father, oh my father:

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What of your father, son?

lg.l: If ever I will here his aged tongue.
Preach to me counsel, or his palsy hand,
Stroke my wild head, and bless me, or his eyes:
Drop tear by tear which they have often done,
At my misgoverned rioting youth.
What should I more, if ever I would see;
The good old man alive. O, o?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Go thy ways for thou shalt have't.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: But do you mean to ride.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Ay grace, all this night.

lg.l: Not all the night without alighting sure:
You'll find more in't then to get up and ride,
The gentleman's riding, boots and spurs.
Why taber?
Nay grace, now's no time.
To stand on scrupulous parting. Knewest thou my business.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: As she shall know it:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: And how I mean this night to toil myself.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Marry hang you brock.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Thou would be moan my travel.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I know 'twould grieve her:

lg.l: You father, grace, good Mr. Harringsfield.
You sir, and all pray for me gentlemen, that in this dark
Night's journey I may find smooth way, sweet speed and
All things to my mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: We'll see my son take horse.

lg.l: But I will stay.
I want the heart to see him post away?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Save you gentlewoman, I have a message to deliver to one mistress Gratiana, this should be the knight's house her father.

lg.l: It is: the message that you have to her.
You may acquaint me with, for I am one
That knows the inside of her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Are you the lady,

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Sir I am the poor gentlewoman ▪

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: There is a cunning woman dwells not far.
At Hogsden lady, famous for her skill.
Besides some private talk that much concerns your fortunes in your love. She hath to show you this night if it shall please you walk so far as to her house, an admirable suit.

lg.l: Of costly needle work, which if you please.
You may by underrate for half the value
It cost the making, about six o'clock .
You may have view thereof, but otherwise.
A lady that hath craved the sight thereof:
Must have the first refusal.
I'll not fail her.
My husband being this day rid from home.
My leisure fitly serves me, thank you mistress?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: At six à clock.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: I will not fail the hour.

lg.l: Now to sir Harry, his is the next place.
To meet at Hogsden his fair daughter grace.

div.head: Actus 5us. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old m. Chartly as new come out of the country to inquire after his son ▪ and three or four serving men with blue coats to attend him.

sp.speaker: ●old Chart.
sp.p: Good heaven; this London is a stranger grown, and out of my acquaintance, this seven years I have not seen Paul's steeple, or cheap, cross.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Hast thou not made inquiry for my son.

lg.l: Yes sir, I have asked about everywhere for him,
But cannot hear of him.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Disperse yourselves ▪ enquire about the taverns, ordinaryes, bowl-allies, tennis courts, gaming-houses. For there (I fear) he will be found.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: But where shall we hear of your worship again.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: At grace church by the conduit, near sir Harry, but stay, leave off a while your bootless search, had e'er man such a wild brain to his sorrow, of such small hope, who when he should have married a fair, a modest, and a virtuous maid, rich and revenued well, and even the night before the marriage day, took horse, road thence whether heaven knows, since the distracted virgin hath left her father's house, but nether feumd, yet in their search we have measured out much ground.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Your worship will be there.

lg.l: Yes, not to f●le.
At half an hour passed six, or before seven.
You shall not find us at six and at seven, I'll
Warrant you: good health to your worship.
Farewell good fellow,
At the wise-woman's house I know it well:
Perhaps she knows some danger touching me.
I'll keep mine hour.
Sir Harry, a hand a hand to balk you it were siun.
I shall be bold to make your house mine inn:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Brother Chartly; I am glad to see you.

lg.l: Methinks sir harry you look strangely on me.
And do not bid me welcome with an heart.
And blame me not to look amazedly,
To see you hear.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Why me?

lg.l: Come come, you're welcome.
And now I'll turn my strangeness to true joy,
I am glad to see you well, and safe recovered ▪
Of your late grievous sickness.
The strange amazed looks that you cast off
You put on me, and blame me not to wonder,
That you should talk of sickness to sound men,
I thank my stars, I did not taste the grief
Of inward pain or outward malady,
This seven years day.
But by your favour brother,
Then let me have my wonder back again.
Before I quite part with it, let me know,
Why you the name of brother put upon me.
In every clause, a name as strange to me:
As my recovered sickness,
You are pleasant,
And it becomes you well, welcome again,
The rather you are come just to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: What wedding sir.

lg.l: That you should ask that question:
Why of my daughter grace.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Is grace bestowed? Of whom I pray,

lg.l: Of whom, but of your son.
I wonder brother Chartly, and my friend,
You should thus play on me.
But by your favour,
Were you ten knights sir Harry, (Take me with you)
My son match with your daughter, my consent,
not worthy to be craved.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nay, than I see:
You'll stir my patience, know this forward match took its first birth from you.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: From me?

lg.l: From you.
Peruse this letter, know you your own hand.
Was well that I reserved, your hand a witness
Against your tongue, you had best deny the jointure,
Of the three hundred pounds made to my daughter,
'Tis that I know you aim at, but your seal.
Shall not make me approve it, I deny
This seal for mine, nor do I vouch that hand,
Your daughter and the dower, letter and all
I quite disclaim, sir Harry you much wrong me.
I can bear more than this, heap wrong on
Wrong, and I'll support it all, I for this time
Will cast my spleen behind me, and yet hear me,
This letter your son Chartly as from you,
Delivered me. I like the motion well.
My spleen is further thrown aside then yours.
And I am full as patient, and yet hear me;
My son's contracted to another maid,
Nay I am patient still, yet that I writ
This letter sealed, this impress I deny.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Why then the jack your hand did counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Why then he did so, where's that unthrift speak?

lg.l: Some hour ago, he mounted and rid post.
To give you visit whom he said lay sick
Upon your deathbed.
You amaze me sir.
It is an ill presage, hereon I see.
Your former salutation took its ground:
To see me safe recovered of my sickness.
Indeed it did, your welcome is a subject.
I cannot use too oft, welcome again,
I am sorry you this night must sup alone:
For I am elsewhere called about some business,
Concerning what I know not, hours run on.
I must to Hogsden, high time I were gone.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.

lg.l: Perhaps to the wise-woman's, she may tell me.
The fortunes of my son, this accident,
Hath bred in me suspicion, and strange fears.
I will not sup alone, but I protest,
Amongst some this night. I'll play the intruding guest.

sp.stage: Exit with his serving-men. Enter the wise-woman, Sencer, Luce and her father, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: But will sir harry come.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Presume he will, and Chartly too.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I'll have the knave by the ears.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay patience sir, leave your revenge to me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Granam I am come according to promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And welcome to the best hole that I have in Hogsden.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Good even.

lg.l: Thanks sir, a good even may it prove,
That each may reap the fruits of their own love:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: That shall be my prayer too.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Come what shall's do.

lg.l: Withdraw, I'll place you all in several rooms.
Where sit, see, but say nothing.
Here sweet mistress, I know the place well ever
Since I was here to know my fortune.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Call me some half an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Your ladyship is most lovingly welcome. A low stool for the gentlewoman boy: I made bold to send to you to take view of such a piece of work, as I presume you have seldom seen the like.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p: Of whose doing, I pray.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: A friend of yours and mine. Please you withdraw I'll bring you to't.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wisew.

lg.l: One calls sweet lady, I shall do you wrong,
But pray you think my little stay not long:

sp.stage: Enter Sencer, sir Harry and Luce.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Here sir in this retiring chamber.

lg.l: Gramercy friend, how now; what's here to do
A pretty wench and a close chamber too.
That you have so much graced my mother's house,
With your desired presence worthy knight.
Receive a poor maids thanks, who's there? A chair
And cushion for fir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Thanks most fair.

lg.l: Please you but a few minutes here to stay:
Till my return, I'll not be long away.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: The gentlewoman will wait on you by and by sir.

lg.l: And I'll attend her friend,
Of all those doubts I long to know the end::

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: The knight you seek was here, or will be straight, and if you be the man you name yourself. You are most welcome, and you shall not back, sill you have scene sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Gentle youth.
I saw him enter here, and under privilege of his acquaintance made I bold to stay.

sp.speaker: ●. Luce.
sp.p: And you are welcome sir, sir down I pray.

lg.l: Now they are placed in several rooms, that look
Into this one. Were Chartly come we had all our company.

sp.speaker: Senser.
sp.p: Hark, there's one knocks 'tis Chartly on my life ▪

sp.speaker: Luce.

lg.l: One of you let him in whilst I prepare me
To entertain his coming.

sp.stage: Enter young Chartly. Usher in by sencer.

lg.l: What? old acquaintance Luce. Not a word?
Yet some lip labour if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: My husband?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What young Chartly?

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: How? My son.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Come, come away with this wailing in woe, if thou puttest finger in the eye a little longer, I shall plunge in pain too presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Husband?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: What sayst thou my sweet wife,

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: Wife? O my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: In that name wife I claim a poor child's part.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband; how have you used me?

lg.l: Nay how do I mean to use thee: but as a man
Should use his wife.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I hope he doth not mean to use her so.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I hope so too,

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: My 〈◊〉 is a witch.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Nay Luce, sweet wife leave weeping if thou lov'st me,

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O can you blame me, knowing that the fountain of all these springs took their first head, from you, you know, you too will know, not three days since are past, since we were married.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Married, I can endure no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Boyst●.
sp.p: I'll be even with thee, for this old granam.

lg.l: And though we wanted witness upon earth,
Yet heaven bears record of our nuptial tie,
Tush, when we, meet in heaven let's talk of that.
Nay come you ass, you fool, what's past is past,
Though man and wife, yet I must marry now.
Another gallant, here's thy letter Luce.
And this night I intend to lodge with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I'll scratch her eyes out first, although I love her.

lg.l: Prithee be merry?
I have made a gull of grace, and old sir Harry thinks me
A great way off, I told the knight,
My father lay a dying, took post-horse ,
Rid out of Holburn, turned by Islington,
So, hither wench to lodge all night with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Here's one saith nay to that,

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Was that your journey:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Why I have too much of grace already ▪

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Thou hast no grace at all.

lg.l: Nay let's to bed, if thou couldst but imagine how
I love thee luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: How is it possible you can love me, and go about to marry another.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Dost thou not know she's rich? Why you fool as soon as I have got her dower, it is but giving her a dram, or a pill to purge melancholy to make her turn up her heels, and then withal that wealth, come I to live with thee my sweet rascal.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: She thanks you, and is much beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: I am betrayed.

lg.l: Art thou my suitor? wouldst thou marry mo● ▪
And thy first wife alive, then poison me,
To purchase my poor dowry.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: What shall I say, or think, or do, I am at ● nonplus.

lg.l: Hast thou the face, thou brazen impudence,
To look upon me passed grace.
Thou canst not properly call me past grace, for
I never enjoyed thee yet: I cannot tell, whether
I blush or no, but I have now at this time,
More grace, than I can tell what to do with.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Who drew thee to this folly?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Who but the old dotard thy father, who when I was honestly married to a civil maid, he persuaded me to leave her, I was loath at first but after entreating, urging, and offering me large proffers, I must confess I was seduced to come a-wooing to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My father, villain.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Ay thy father grace. And were he here I would justify it to the old dotard's face.

lg.l: Vild boy thou dar'st not be so impudent.
When did I meet thee, seek or sue to thee:
When? Name the day, the month, the hour, the year.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Plots, plots. I can but cry you mercy both, say that I have done you wrong, I can be but sorry for it, but indeed to clear you, and lay the fault where it ought to be. All this comes from mine own father in the country, who hearing I had married with Luce. Sends me word of. his blessing to be divorced from her, and to come a suitor to your daughter, I think you have his hand and seal to show.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: My hand and seal, when was that letter writ.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Heyda, if you get one word more of me tonight , but scurvy looks, I'll give you leave to hang me ▪

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Vild boy,

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Ungracious villain.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Treacherous youth?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No grace at all?

sp.speaker: Ch●t.
sp.p: No grace.

lg.l: This is bad company who hath reduced thee?
Speak on my blessing, who hath thus misled thee?
But no more lies I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Bad company hath been the shame of me, I was as virtuously given as any youth in Europe, till I fell into one Boyster's company, 'tis he that hath done all the harm upon me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And if he should deny it?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: What then you'd cry him mercy.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I had best bite out my tongue, and speak no more what shall I do, or what shall I say, there is no outfacing them all gentlemen, fathers, wives, or what else. I have wronged you all. I confess it that I have, what would you more, will any of you rail of me? Ill bear it, will any of you beat me? So they strike not too hard I'll suffer it, will any of you challenge me? I'll answer it. What would you have me say, or do? One of these I have married, the other I have betrothed, yet both maids for me; will you have me take one, and leave the tother? I will, will you have me keep them both? I will.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Perjured not mine.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What you here too? Nay then I see all my good friends are met together, wilt thou have me luce? I am thy husband, and had I not loved thee better than grace. I had not disappointed the marriage day tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Lascivious no,

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Wilt thou have me grace, for had I not loved thee better than luce. I would never after I had married her been contracted to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Inconstant no,

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then neither married man, widow nor bachelor, what's to be done? Here's even the proverb verified, between too stools, the tail goes to ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Now I bethink me this our meeting here is wondrous strange, call in the gentlewoman that owns this house.

div.stage: Enter Sencer and the wise-woman, he like a gentleman ▪

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Old trot, I'll trounce thee.
Here is the marriage proved twixt Luce and Chartly, witch this was not your promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Have patience, and in the end we'll pay you all. Your worships are most heartily welcome, I made bold to send for you, and you may see to what end, which was to discover unto you, the wild vagaries of this, of this wanton wag pasty, a will-doats I warrant him, and sir Harry that your daughter hath 'scaped this skouring, thank this gentleman, and then make of him as he deserves.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: O, I remember him.

lg.l: He never pleased mine eye so well as now.
I know his love, and he in Chartley's place
My favour shall possess.

sp.speaker: S●ncer.
sp.p: Thanks my sweet grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ay and the more the inconstant youth to spite.

sp.speaker: Sencer,
sp.p: I gave her thee in Chartley's sight.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: There's one gone already, but this is my wife and her I'll keep in spite both of the devil and his dam.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Not from her lawful husband.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That am I.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: That is the gentleman, accept ▪ him Luce.
And you then like of her, nay I'll make it good,
This gentleman married you vizarded, you him disguised mistaking him for Chartly, which none but my boy Jack was privy too: after she changed her habit with him, as you with Jack.
And you in mistress Luce's habit.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: May I believe you mother.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: This be your token.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Her that I married, I wrong twice by the finger.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Of that token, my hand was sensible.

lg.l: And ere the clamorous and loud noise be gone,
I whispered to her thus.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are the man,

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Thanks granam, what thou promised thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And leaving him, I take you for my son.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Two gone, then where's the third, this makes me mad, where is my wife then, for a wife I had.

lg.l: Not see thy wife. Come hither jack my boy.
Nay take him to thee, and with him all joy.
Well art thou served to be a general scorn,
To all thy blood: and if not for our sakes,
For thy soul's health and credit of the world,
Have some regarded to me, to me thy father.
Enough sir: if I should say I would become
A new man; you would not take my word.
If I should swear. I would amend my life,
You would not take mine oath, if I should bind myself, to become an honest man you would scarce take my bond.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: I should do none of these.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Then see sir, when to all your judgements I see me passed grace, do lay hold of grace, and here begin to retire myself, this woman hath lent me a glass, in which I see all my imperfections, at which my conscience doth more blush inwardly, than my face outwardly, and now I dare confidently undertake for myself I am honest.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Then I dare confidently undertake to help you to a wife who desires to have an honest man or none, look on me well, simple though I stand here I am your wife, blush not at your folly man, perhaps I have more in me, than you expect from me.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Knavery and riot both which, are now to me mean forage.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: You and I have been better acquainted and yet search me not too far lest you shame me, look on me well, nay better, better yet, I'll assure you I left of a petticoat when I put on these breeches,
What say you now, she scatters her hair.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: First love, and best beloved?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Let me be both or neither.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: My boy turned girl I hope she'll keep my counsel from henceforth, I'll never entertain any servant but I'll have her searched.

lg.l: Her love hath drawn her hither after him.
My loving daughter welcome thou hast run,
A happy course to see my son thus changed.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Father, call me once again your son, and sir harry me your friend: sencer an hand, and mistress grace an heart, in honourable love. Where I have wronged you luce forgive. Impute my errors to my youth not me, with grace I interchange, an embrace with you luce, a parting buss I wish you all joy, divide my part amongst you, thou my soul.
Nay mother midnight there's some love for you.
Out of thy folly, being reputed wise,
We, self conceited ha● our folly's found:
Bear thou the name of all these comic acts.

lg.l: Luce and grace, (Oh covetous man) I see,
I sought to engross what now sufficeth three.
Yet each one wife, enough, one nuptial feast:
Shall serve three bridals where, be thou chief guest.

div.head: To his chosen friend, the learned author Mr. Thomas Heywood.
div.l: Thou wants no herald to divulge thy fame;
It needs no apology; only thy name;
Into judicious readers, doth infuse;
A will: to add a laurel to thy muse;
Was now Maecenas living. How would he
Support thy learned wit? Whose industry
Hath purchased such a knowing skill ▪ that those
Who read admire thee; less some critic shows
His ignorance in seeking with new songs,
To gain the honour; which to thee belongs.
But let pale envy belch forth all her spite
Thy candid fame shalt still contain white
Unspotted, pure, and fair, till memory,
Be turned oblivion, or ● deity,
Prove mortal; and when Atropos, shall do
The fatal office, her belongs unto;
Apollo will rebreath a life in thee,
In length to equal all eternity
Where in Elyzian joys he will so raise
Thy worth where never wither shall 〈◊〉 the bays
Wherewith he crowns thee; so thy works will show.
The debt, I pay 'sno more but what I owe.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
